User.title: User
User.description: Represents a user of the StudioZen application.

id.description: Unique identifier for the User entity.

name.description: The display name of the user.

schoolType.description: The user's type of school (e.g., high school, university).

learningStyle.description: The user's preferred learning style, used to tailor AI-generated content.

WebsiteBlock.title: WebsiteBlock
WebsiteBlock.description: Represents a website or application that is blocked for a user.

id.description: Unique identifier for the WebsiteBlock entity.

url.description: The URL of the website to block.

startTime.description: Start time for blocking the URL, if applicable. (date-time format)

endTime.description: End time for blocking the URL, if applicable. (date-time format)

FocusSession.title: FocusSession
FocusSession.description: Represents a focus session using the Pomodoro timer.

id.description: Unique identifier for the FocusSession entity.

startTime.description: The start time of the focus session. (date-time format)

endTime.description: The end time of the focus session. (date-time format)

duration.description: The duration of the focus session in minutes.

interruptionCount.description: The number of times the user was interrupted during the focus session.

params.description: The unique identifier of the user.

firestore.reasoning: The Firestore structure is designed to ensure secure and scalable data management for the StudioZen application, focusing on authorization independence and clear data ownership. User-specific data (WebsiteBlocks, FocusSessions) is stored under path-based ownership (`/users/{userId}/...`), ensuring only the owning user can access their data. This structure avoids the need for complex security rules that require reading parent documents, thus enabling atomic operations. WebsiteBlock and FocusSession entities will exist as subcollections of user documents to ensure that the authenticated user has access to this information. This approach achieves authorization independence by leveraging the inherent path-based ownership in Firestore, which simplifies security rules and enhances performance. The use of dedicated subcollections ensures that each collection maintains a homogeneous security posture, streamlining rule definitions and improving debuggability. This approach facilitates secure `list` operations, as each subcollection inherently belongs to a specific user, preventing unauthorized access.
